name: FINAL CUT
description:
The Final Cut is a class library and widget toolkit with full mouse support for creating a text-based user interface. The library supports the programmer to develop an application for the text console. It allows the simultaneous handling of multiple windows on the screen.
The C++ class design was inspired by the Qt framework. It provides common controls like dialog windows, push buttons, check boxes, radio buttons, input lines, list boxes, status bars and so on.

name: libseccomp
description: The libseccomp library provides an easy to use, platform independent, interface to the Linux Kernel's syscall filtering mechanism.  The libseccomp API is designed to abstract away the underlying BPF based syscall filter language and present a more conventional function-call based filtering interface that should be familiar to, and easily adopted by, application developers.
interact_justification: Project releases are documented on the GitHub release page: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/releases>.  Information on interacting with the project can be found in the README and CONTRIBUTING files: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/README.md> <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_justification: The contribution process is documented in the CONTRIBUTING file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: The contribution requirements are documented in the CONTRIBUTING file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The LGPL-2.1 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The LGPL-2.1 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The libseccomp API is documented via man-pages: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/tree/master/doc>.
documentation_interface_justification: The libseccomp API is documented via man-pages: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/tree/master/doc>.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The GitHub repository is the authoritative repository for the libseccomp project.  All code development/changes are made via the public GitHub repository.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The project provides unique version numbers for all official releases: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/releases>.
version_tags_justification: Each release is tagged with the format "v<MAJOR>.<MINOR>.<MICRO>", e.g. "v2.3.1".  Branches are created for each major/minor release combination with the format "release-<MAJOR>.<MINOR>", e.g. "release-2.3".
release_notes_justification: Each release is made with a change log summary on the release page: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/releases>.  In addition, the entire projects change log summary is tracked in the CHANGELOG file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CHANGELOG>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Known vulnerabilities are documented in the repository history and change log.
report_tracker_justification: The GitHub issue tracker is used to track individual issues.
report_process_justification: Bug reports may be submitted via the mailing list or GitHub issue tracker: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/issues>.
report_responses_justification: All bug reports to the mailing list and the GitHub issue tracker have been acknowledged by the development team.  The libseccomp development team strives to respond to user issues within a time frame measured in days, not months.
enhancement_responses_justification: All requests to the mailing list and the GitHub issue tracker have been acknowledged by the development team.  While it make take some time to fully satisfy the enhancement requests, the development team strives to respond to requests within a time frame measured in days, not months.
report_archive_justification: The GitHub issue tracker can be found at the following URL: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/issues>.  The public mailing list is archived at the following URL: <https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/libseccomp>.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: This is documented in the project's README file: https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/README.md
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: This is documented in the project's README file: https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/README.md
build_justification: The project uses the traditional autoconf and automake tools to generate a working Makefile based build system.
test_justification: The test suite is included with the project and instructions on running the tests can be found in the README and CONTRIBUTING files.
test_invocation_justification: The tests can be run using "make check" from the top directory of a local configured source repository.
test_most_justification: Code coverage is now being tracked via gcov and Coveralls: <https://coveralls.io/github/seccomp/libseccomp>
tests_are_added_justification: See the git log for more information.
warnings_justification: By default the build is done with "-Wall" passed to the compiler.
warnings_fixed_justification: The development team is not aware of any build warnings on a modern Linux system and works to address any warnings as they are discovered.
warnings_strict_justification: The development team is not aware of any build warnings on a modern Linux system and works to address any warnings as they are discovered.
delivery_mitm_justification: The project's source code repository and releases are protected via ssh and https.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The project's releases are protected via https, including the release checksums that are also PGP signed.
static_analysis_justification: All releases are tested with Coverity: <https://scan.coverity.com/projects/libseccomp>.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The project currently makes use of the clang, Coverity, and LGTM to static analysis tools.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: All defects identified by static analysis are resolved prior to release.
static_analysis_often_justification: The Travis CI configuration includes the clang "scan-build" tool: <https://travis-ci.org/seccomp/libseccomp>
dynamic_analysis_justification: Dynamic testing with valgrind is included as part of the bundled test suite on platforms that provide valgrind support.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Dynamic testing with valgrind is included as part of the bundled test suite on platforms that provide valgrind support.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: All defects identified by dynamic analysis are resolved quickly as part of the development process.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The project's GitHub repository is integrated with Travis CI: <https://travis-ci.org/seccomp/libseccomp>
discussion_justification: The project has an associated mailing list as well as the normal GitHub collaboration features, e.g. issue tracking and pull-requests.
english_justification: All project documentation and communications occur in English.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
installation_common_justification: While libseccomp does provide the standard automake install/uninstall targets, it is expected that most users of the libseccomp library will use their distribution's package manager to install/uninstall the libseccomp library.
dco_justification: There is a DCO documented in the CONTRIBUTING file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
governance_justification: There is only one role, that of "maintainer", which is documented in the MAINTAINER_PROCESS.md file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/doc/admin/MAINTAINER_PROCESS.md>
code_of_conduct_justification: There is a section, "Interacting with the Community", in the CONTRIBUTING.md file which describes the expected behavior of those involved with the project.  The CONTRIBUTING.md file can be found here: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md>
roles_responsibilities_justification: There is only one key role within the project, that of maintainer.  The documents describing the maintainer role, the release process, etc. can be found in the doc/admin directory of the project: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/tree/main/doc/admin>
access_continuity_justification: There are two project maintainers with each having the necessary permissions to continue the project; the maintainers are listed in the project's README.md which can be found here: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/main/README.md>
bus_factor_justification: There are two project maintainers with each having the necessary permissions to continue the project; the maintainers are listed in the project's README.md which can be found here: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/main/README.md>
documentation_roadmap_justification: The project is managed via GitHub milestones with the current milestones visible here: https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/milestones
documentation_current_justification: The documentation, in the form of manpages, is kept in the repository with the project sources.  The manpages can be found here: https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/tree/main/doc/man
documentation_achievements_justification: Badges are documented in the README.md which is displayed on the project page on GitHub: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/README.md>
internationalization_justification: The libseccomp project is not a end-user visible project, the project's users are other developers who wish to make use of the library in their applications.
sites_password_security_justification: The project is hosted on GitHub which meets this criterion according to the requirement details above.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Previous releases are supported whenever possible, and all of the new libseccomp v2.x releases are ABI compatible with previous libseccomp v2.x releases.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: We have only had one CVE level vulnerability with libseccomp, and the security researcher was credited in the GH issue and the commit which fixed the bug: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/issues/139>
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: The security vulnerability process is documented in the SECURITY.md file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/SECURITY.md>
coding_standards_justification: The style guidelines are enforced via tools included with the project and documented in the CONTRIBUTING.md file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>
coding_standards_enforced_justification: The style guidelines are enforced via tools included with the project and documented in the CONTRIBUTING.md file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>
build_standard_variables_justification: The project relies on autoconf/automake which provides this functionality.
build_preserve_debug_justification: The project relies on autoconf/automake which provides this functionality.
installation_standard_variables_justific: The project relies on autoconf/automake which provides this functionality.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: The project uses Travis CI is used for CI testing of all PRs and branches.
regression_tests_added50_justification: The project has an extensive regression test suite with over 90% code coverage as of June 2020.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: The project has an extensive regression test suite with over 90% code coverage as of June 2020.
test_policy_mandated_justification: This is a listed requirement in the CONTRIBUTING.md file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>
input_validation_justification: Inputs to the API functions are validated whenever possible, and regular static analysis (via clang, Coverity, etc.) are used to help verify this.
signed_releases_justification: All project releases, both artifacts and git tags, are signed with gpg and verification instructions for the release artifacts are included in the README.md file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/README.md>
version_tags_signed_justification: All project releases, both artifacts and git tags, are signed with gpg and verification instructions for the release artifacts are included in the README.md file: <https://github.com/seccomp/libseccomp/blob/master/README.md>

name: OpenDaylight
description: OpenDaylight is a highly available, modular, extensible, scalable and multi-protocol controller infrastructure built for SDN deployments on modern heterogeneous multi-vendor networks. OpenDaylight provides a model-driven service abstraction platform that allows users to write apps that easily work across a wide variety of hardware and south-bound protocols.
description_good_justification:
OpenDaylight: Open Source SDN Platform
Software-Defined Networking (SDN) is an industry movement for building programmable networks that are flexible and responsive to organizations' and users' needs.
contribution_justification:
Project uses pull requests.
https://docs.opendaylight.org/en/latest/#contributing-to-opendaylight
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://docs.opendaylight.org/en/latest/#contributing-to-opendaylight

  (a) The contribution was created in whole or in part by me and I
            have the right to submit it under the open source license
            indicated in the file; or

        (b) The contribution is based upon previous work that, to the best
            of my knowledge, is covered under an appropriate open source
            license and I have the right under that license to submit that
            work with modifications, whether created in whole or in part
            by me, under the same open source license (unless I am
            permitted to submit under a different license), as indicated
            in the file; or

        (c) The contribution was provided directly to me by some other
            person who certified (a), (b) or (c) and I have not modified
            it.

        (d) I understand and agree that this project and the contribution
            are public and that a record of the contribution (including all
            personal information I submit with it, including my sign-off) is
            maintained indefinitely and may be redistributed consistent with
            this project or the open source license(s) involved.

name: dpkg
description:
Debian package management system.

Dpkg provides the low-level infrastructure for handling the  installation and removal of Debian software packages.
contribution_justification: https://wiki.debian.org/Teams/Dpkg/Contribute
license_location_justification: https://git.dpkg.org/git/dpkg/dpkg.git/tree/COPYING
documentation_basics_justification: The source tree contains documentation in the doc/ and man/ directories, which get installed. All public Perl module interfaces are documented with POD, which gets converted to man pages and installed. The libdpkg library is documented with Doxygen (although this is still work in progress, following the current state of libdpkg), and HTML generated output can be found linked from the home page.
documentation_interface_justification: All public interfaces are documented in man pages, or in the doc/ directory.
repo_public_justification: Uses git.
repo_track_justification: Uses git.
repo_distributed_justification: Uses git.
version_semver_justification: The current version schema uses a static major, because most functionality keeps being backwards compatible, followed by a minor version that increases on each Debian distribution release, followed by a micro which gets incremented on each dpkg release.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Every vulnerability with a known and public CVE, gets referenced in the changelog.
report_tracker_justification: The Debian BTS supports multiple bug reports per project.
report_responses_justification: Most bug reports either get fixed straight away, or should get a response asking for more information, or stating why the bug cannot be fixed, or how it might get fixed.
build_floss_tools_justification: The package is distributed in Debian main, which means that it only build-depends and depends on FLOSS tools.
test_justification: There are a set of in-tree unit and functional tests. And there is an external functional test suite (https://git.dpkg.org/cgit/dpkg/dpkg-tests.git).
test_invocation_justification: The test suites can be invoked via make. https://git.dpkg.org/cgit/dpkg/dpkg.git/tree/README
test_most_justification: This is work in progress, the project did not initially have any kind of test suite.
warnings_justification:
As many warnings as possible are enabled for gcc and/or clang, as long as they are not stylistic, or produce false-positives.

https://git.dpkg.org/git/dpkg/dpkg.git/tree/m4/dpkg-compiler.m4
warnings_fixed_justification: The project does not currently have known warnings, at least when built on the main development systems.
warnings_strict_justification:
.As many warnings as possible are enabled for gcc and/or clang, as long as they are not stylistic, or produce false-positives.

https://git.dpkg.org/git/dpkg/dpkg.git/tree/m4/dpkg-compiler.m4
static_analysis_justification: At least one of cppcheck, clang static analyzer or Coverity Quality Analyzer is run for each release that has changed C or C++ code. For perl code perlcritic is executed as part of the author unit tests.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j:
cppcheck is used as part of the author tests.

https://git.dpkg.org/git/dpkg/dpkg.git/tree/t/cppcheck.t
static_analysis_often_justification:
Various static analyzers are run from time to time, in principle at least before every release. Currently at least cppcheck is run automatically on each push. Other static analyzers are currently not automatically run, because these have not been setup, or because the static analyzers have rate limits on the amount of times they can be run.

https://git.dpkg.org/cgit/dpkg/dpkg.git/tree/t/cppcheck.t
dynamic_analysis_justification: This is still not the case, while it should eventually get done. Missing setup and automation mostly.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: This only done sporadically as of now.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: The code-base is very strict with error conditions, and those should be handled at run-time.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: All such bugs that have been reported up-to-now have been fixed in a timely way.
discussion_justification: The project has a public mailing list (https://lists.debian.org/debian-dpkg/), and a public bug tracking system (https://bugs.debian.org/src:dpkg).
english_justification: English is the official language of the project.
hardening_justification: Various hardening build flags are used by default when building the Debian packages. https://git.dpkg.org/cgit/dpkg/dpkg.git/tree/debian/rules
crypto_used_network_justification: The only parts that use HTTP are the dselect download methods, and those should be verifying the contents via OpenPGP anyway. So while using HTTPS can be good, the security revolves around signed indexes.
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.
installation_common_justification: The projects supports the make install/uninstall with DESTDIR convention. It is also packaged and available within most major distributions (https://wiki.debian.org/Teams/Dpkg/Downstream).
dco_justification: There is none in place, as it is assumed people contributing understand what that entails.
code_of_conduct_justification: There's been no need for this. There is the parent Code of Conduct from the Debian project which is in place given that the project uses the Debian resources.
access_continuity_justification: All the current infrastructure is hosted by the Debian project, which means any Debian Developer can contribute or Debian service administrators can perform any permission transition. https://wiki.debian.org/Teams/Dpkg
documentation_current_justification: Documentation is an important aspect of the project, and any issues, and improvement requests are always taken into consideration and fixed.
internationalization_justification: The bulk of the project has i18n support, and it has been translated to many languages.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Each minor branch 1.x (e.g. 1.19.x) is maintained as long as the Debian release which includes it is maintained. Each of those minor branches can be upgraded to the next minor branch (e.g. 1.18.x to 1.19.x), in the same way any Debian release can be upgraded to the next one.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: For the C code the current coding style is difficult to enforce automatically, no available tool seems able to do it. For the Perl code the coding style is enforced via the test suite.
dependency_monitoring_justification: This is handled as part of distributions duties.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: Where cryptographic hashes are used, multiple are supported, with non-weak ones among them.
signed_releases_justification: The releases are done as standard Debian source and binary builds, which include a OpenPGP signed source description file .dsc, and a signed upload description file .changes.
version_tags_signed_justification: Each new git tag is signed.
license_per_file_justification: Each copyrightable file contains a license statement.
require_2FA_justification: The repository is self-hosted and only a few developers have restricted git access via ssh.
two_person_review_justification: There is mainly a primary developer, and sporadic contributors. Most changes do not get peer public review. Although the code gets reviewed by others, but the results might only be let known when some problem is found.

name: privacyIDEA
contribution_justification: https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst
contribution_requirements_justification:
We explain e.g. how translations can be done.
https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst

When contributing via issues at github, we use the template, so that the issuer will provide all necessary information.
https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/blob/master/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_interface_justification:
There are different interfaces. The Python Module interfaces, when developing modules for privacyIDEA and the REST API, when performing HTTP requests when e.g. implementing plugins for third party applications.
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules/index.html

Python Modules:
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules/lib.html

REST API:
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules/api.html
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules/api/validate.html
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We are tagging versions like 2.18dev0, 2.18dev1 to illustrate, a certain milestone on the way to the release. We are also using branches for features and fixes of already published versions. (Branch 2.16.1 while already working on 2.17)
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: A realease gets a tag in the git repository. This version is also published at the python package index and in a launchpad repository.
version_tags_justification: We are using tags for development snapshots and for released versions.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/blob/master/Changelog>.
release_notes_vulns_justification:
Public know vulnerabilities or bugs have an issue number at github.
The Changelog references the issue numbers and each release has a section with "Fixes".
https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/blob/master/Changelog
report_tracker_justification:
We are using the github issue tracker:
https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/issues/
report_process_justification:
We use a google group as mailing list. If questions appear to be bugs, the users are asked to open an issue or we are openen an issue for this problem.
https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/issues/
report_archive_justification:
We are using github and a discourse installation (we used to use a google group)
https://community.privacyidea.org
crypto_published_justification:
privacyIDEA provides standardized two factor authentication. Several OTP protocols are defined in RFC like OATH HOTP/TOTP/OCRA.
Database encryption is performed using AES with IV.
There are different standard hashing and key derivation functions in place.
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/crypto-considerations.html
crypto_call_justification: We are using default crypto primitives implemented by various python modules.
crypto_floss_justification: The complete server backend (privacyIDEA) is licenced under AGPLv3.
crypto_keylength_justification:
The SSL certificate is generated with 2048 bit keylength.
AES 256 is used. SHA256 and SHA512.
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/crypto-considerations.html
crypto_working_justification:
The project does not depend on this.
However MD5 is used for a special tokentype - the motp token.
It uses md5 to calculate the hash from input data. 
1. But the user is free to use this token type or not.
2. The md5 result is in fact truncated, so that the probability of guessing the next OTP value is rather low, since there is not the complete hash for calculating collisions.
crypto_random_justification:
If needed privacyIDEA also supports HSMs.
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installation/system/securitymodule.html?highlight=HSM
delivery_mitm_justification:
The API and Webfrontend runs on Https when the default packages are created.
https://github.com/privacyidea/privacyidea/blob/master/deploy/debian-ubuntu/privacyidea-apache2.postinst#L50
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
The HOTP and TOTP algorithm depend on SHA1. However, in fact they depend on HMAC-SHA-1 which is not broken. 
Read https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4226#page-26
PrivacyIDEA uses sha2.
http://privacyidea.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/crypto-considerations.html
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification:
The issues at github are filed in English language.
The google group for discussions also uses the English language.
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/privacyidea
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". # X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
